_description: Four rhyming lines at end of Serpent of Division, quoting ‘my maister Chaucer’

BLAdd48031.Transcription: With boidkynnes was Cesar JuliusMurdrid at Rome of Brutus cassusWhan many a regeon he had broughte ful loweLoo whoo may truste fortvne any throwe
BLAdd48031.Note: The longer prose text in which this verse is embedded ends on f. 175v with “Here endeth the cronycule of Julius Cesar Emperoure of Rome tyme specifying cavse of the Ruyne and Destruccion of þe same Citie translated by me Danna John lidgate nomke of Bury Seint Edmund the yere of our lord god ml iiij c.”

CamMagPep2006.Transcription:
Wyth Bodekyne was Cesar JuliusMurdred at Rome of brutus
                    CassiusWhen mony land and regne hadd brought ful loweloo who may trust
                    fortune eny throwe
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.

HarEng530.Transcription:
With boidekynes was Cesar JuliusMordred at Rome of Brutus
                    CassiusWhan many londe & Regne had brought ful loweLo who may
                    trust ffortune eny throwe

Robinson,  F. N.
